subject: sharding: first attempt at _elect_leader
messages:
[{'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-06-26 10:54:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-06-26 10:55:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

WIP, code in sharder hasn't been finished yet, but wanted to get this code up."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-06-28 07:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-07-02 05:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-07-22 09:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-10-08 03:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2020-04-20 07:15:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2020-04-21 04:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2020-06-04 01:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-06-04 06:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(5 comments)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 10:54:47.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: first attempt at _elect_leader

This patch builds up from the last in the chain and implements
an initial version of the _elect_leader code in the sharder.

It starts by adding a little more to the ELECT container server verb
by also returning the db state. Why? Because it means we can be
smarter about making a decision. (Though I should push this in the
previous patch in the chain).

Currently the auto-sharding has been implemented to search for x shards,
add them, and then next round find the next x. So scanning takes a while.
With the OP driven sharding, we scan for _all_ the shard ranges and then
insert them. This seems to be working even on large containers.
I wonder if we should do the same in auto sharding? Scan for them all,
check to see if we are still the leader (the authority on shard ranges)
and if so insert them.
By getting the db state we can make a decison. I.E if one of the other
primaries are already in the the SHARDING or SHARDED state then the
election should fail as someone else has inserted something (an OP
or a split brain leader election thing).

We are being very safe, initially using an ALL primary majority. This
could mean that on very large containers by the time the leader has
finally scanned all ranges and ready to insert, a rebalance may have
taken place and potentially a new leader will need to start again.
Turns out if we ever get into a state that means the container can't
progress then we have the OP tool to fall back on.

An ELECT call returns a json response in the form of:

  {"node": <index 0 node dict from ring>,
   "part": <ring partition>,
   "status": <db status>,
   "version": <ring version>}

The current implementation goes something like this:
 - Send an ELECT call to all other primaries and gather responses.
 - Decide if I am the scanner based on some all the responses, including
my own. These entail:
    ~ False if number of responses is < quorum
    ~ If there is more then one index 0 node (comparing only IP and
      PORT) then filter the responses to only those with the latest ring
      version[0].
    ~ False if any of the responses are in SHARDING or SHARDED state.
    ~ Make sure at least a quorum of responses are UNSHARDED[1]
    ~ True if there is still a quorum of responses that think it's me[2]
    ~ otherwise return false

This obviously only works in a scan all ranges scenario, currently the
code hasn't been modified to this, it's still X by X mode.

[0] - If there is a new ring version it might not effect our primaries,
so if they all agree it's me regardless on ring version then great
(though I haven't added a return True here yet cause still not
convinced).

[1] - At the moment we on ALL quorum, if this ever changes we want a
quorum of primaries to agree noting that we'd have bombed out if we found
any in the SHARDING or SHARDED state. Why this then, if we hit a node
that doesn't have the DB (either because it's new or it's replicated it
away already) then the db state will be NOTFOUND. But it still has a
ring so should know who it thinks index 0 should be, so maybe it's vote
still means something.

[2] - This guy is convinced he is index 0, so just confirming, if it
isn't then _elect_leader will return false (ie well it isn't me then).

Change-Id: I7f9b3769406b1d139d75aaca166bdb1355b14b1a
'}, {'created': '2019-06-28 07:17:52.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: first attempt at _elect_leader

This patch builds up from the last in the chain and implements
an initial version of the _elect_leader code in the sharder.

Currently the auto-sharding has been implemented to search for x shards,
add them, and then next round find the next x. So scanning takes a while.
With the OP driven sharding, we scan for _all_ the shard ranges and then
insert them. This seems to be working even on large containers.
I wonder if we should do the same in auto sharding? Scan for them all,
check to see if we are still the leader (the authority on shard ranges)
and if so insert them.
By using the db state we can make a decison. I.E if one of the other
primaries are already in the the SHARDING or SHARDED state then the
election should fail as someone else has inserted something (an OP
or a split brain leader election thing).

We are being very safe, initially using an ALL primary majority. This
could mean that on very large containers by the time the leader has
finally scanned all ranges and ready to insert, a rebalance may have
taken place and potentially a new leader will need to start again.
Turns out if we ever get into a state that means the container can't
progress then we have the OP tool to fall back on.

An ELECT call returns a json response in the form of:

  {"node": <index 0 node dict from ring>,
   "part": <ring partition>,
   "status": <db status>,
   "version": <ring version>}

The current implementation goes something like this:
 - Send an ELECT call to all other primaries and gather responses.
 - Decide if I am the scanner based on some all the responses, including
my own. These entail:
    ~ False if number of responses is < quorum
    ~ If there is more then one index 0 node (comparing only IP and
      PORT) then filter the responses to only those with the latest ring
      version[0].
    ~ False if any of the responses are in SHARDING or SHARDED state.
    ~ Make sure at least a quorum of responses are UNSHARDED[1]
    ~ True if there is still a quorum of responses that think it's me[2]
    ~ otherwise return false

This obviously only works in a scan all ranges scenario, currently the
code hasn't been modified to this, it's still X by X mode.

[0] - If there is a new ring version it might not effect our primaries,
so if they all agree it's me regardless on ring version then great
(though I haven't added a return True here yet cause still not
convinced).

[1] - At the moment we on ALL quorum, if this ever changes we want a
quorum of primaries to agree noting that we'd have bombed out if we found
any in the SHARDING or SHARDED state. Why this then, if we hit a node
that doesn't have the DB (either because it's new or it's replicated it
away already) then the db state will be NOTFOUND. But it still has a
ring so should know who it thinks index 0 should be, so maybe it's vote
still means something.

[2] - This guy is convinced he is index 0, so just confirming, if it
isn't then _elect_leader will return false (ie well it isn't me then).

Change-Id: I7f9b3769406b1d139d75aaca166bdb1355b14b1a
'}, {'created': '2019-07-02 05:18:02.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: first attempt at _elect_leader

This patch builds up from the last in the chain and implements
an initial version of the _elect_leader code in the sharder.

Currently the auto-sharding has been implemented to search for x shards,
add them, and then next round find the next x. So scanning takes a while.
With the OP driven sharding, we scan for _all_ the shard ranges and then
insert them. This seems to be working even on large containers.
I wonder if we should do the same in auto sharding? Scan for them all,
check to see if we are still the leader (the authority on shard ranges)
and if so insert them.
By using the db state we can make a decison. I.E if one of the other
primaries are already in the the SHARDING or SHARDED state then the
election should fail as someone else has inserted something (an OP
or a split brain leader election thing).

We are being very safe, initially using an ALL primary majority. This
could mean that on very large containers by the time the leader has
finally scanned all ranges and ready to insert, a rebalance may have
taken place and potentially a new leader will need to start again.
Turns out if we ever get into a state that means the container can't
progress then we have the OP tool to fall back on.

An ELECT call returns a json response in the form of:

  {"node": <index 0 node dict from ring>,
   "part": <ring partition>,
   "status": <db status>,
   "version": <ring version>}

The current implementation goes something like this:
 - Send an ELECT call to all other primaries and gather responses.
 - Decide if I am the scanner based on some all the responses, including
my own. These entail:
    ~ False if number of responses is < quorum
    ~ If there is more then one index 0 node (comparing only IP and
      PORT) then filter the responses to only those with the latest ring
      version[0].
    ~ False if any of the responses are in SHARDING or SHARDED state.
    ~ Make sure at least a quorum of responses are UNSHARDED[1]
    ~ True if there is still a quorum of responses that think it's me[2]
    ~ otherwise return false

This obviously only works in a scan all ranges scenario, currently the
code hasn't been modified to this, it's still X by X mode.

[0] - If there is a new ring version it might not effect our primaries,
so if they all agree it's me regardless on ring version then great
(though I haven't added a return True here yet cause still not
convinced).

[1] - At the moment we on ALL quorum, if this ever changes we want a
quorum of primaries to agree noting that we'd have bombed out if we found
any in the SHARDING or SHARDED state. Why this then, if we hit a node
that doesn't have the DB (either because it's new or it's replicated it
away already) then the db state will be NOTFOUND. But it still has a
ring so should know who it thinks index 0 should be, so maybe it's vote
still means something.

[2] - This guy is convinced he is index 0, so just confirming, if it
isn't then _elect_leader will return false (ie well it isn't me then).

Change-Id: I7f9b3769406b1d139d75aaca166bdb1355b14b1a

commit_message:
sharding: first attempt at _elect_leader

This patch builds up from the last in the chain and implements
an initial version of the _elect_leader code in the sharder.

Currently the auto-sharding has been implemented to search for x shards,
add them, and then next round find the next x. So scanning takes a while.
With the OP driven sharding, we scan for _all_ the shard ranges and then
insert them. This seems to be working even on large containers.
I wonder if we should do the same in auto sharding? Scan for them all,
check to see if we are still the leader (the authority on shard ranges)
and if so insert them.
By using the db state we can make a decison. I.E if one of the other
primaries are already in the the SHARDING or SHARDED state then the
election should fail as someone else has inserted something (an OP
or a split brain leader election thing).

We are being very safe, initially using an ALL primary majority. This
could mean that on very large containers by the time the leader has
finally scanned all ranges and ready to insert, a rebalance may have
taken place and potentially a new leader will need to start again.
Turns out if we ever get into a state that means the container can't
progress then we have the OP tool to fall back on.

An ELECT call returns a json response in the form of:

  {"node": <index 0 node dict from ring>,
   "part": <ring partition>,
   "status": <db status>,
   "version": <ring version>}

The current implementation goes something like this:
 - Send an ELECT call to all other primaries and gather responses.
 - Decide if I am the scanner based on some all the responses, including
my own. These entail:
    ~ False if number of responses is < quorum
    ~ If there is more then one index 0 node (comparing only IP and
      PORT) then filter the responses to only those with the latest ring
      version[0].
    ~ False if any of the responses are in SHARDING or SHARDED state.
    ~ Make sure at least a quorum of responses are UNSHARDED[1]
    ~ True if there is still a quorum of responses that think it's me[2]
    ~ otherwise return false

This obviously only works in a scan all ranges scenario, currently the
code hasn't been modified to this, it's still X by X mode.

[0] - If there is a new ring version it might not effect our primaries,
so if they all agree it's me regardless on ring version then great
(though I haven't added a return True here yet cause still not
convinced).

[1] - At the moment we on ALL quorum, if this ever changes we want a
quorum of primaries to agree noting that we'd have bombed out if we found
any in the SHARDING or SHARDED state. Why this then, if we hit a node
that doesn't have the DB (either because it's new or it's replicated it
away already) then the db state will be NOTFOUND. But it still has a
ring so should know who it thinks index 0 should be, so maybe it's vote
still means something.

[2] - This guy is convinced he is index 0, so just confirming, if it
isn't then _elect_leader will return false (ie well it isn't me then).

Change-Id: I7f9b3769406b1d139d75aaca166bdb1355b14b1a

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-28 15:21:14.000000000', 'message': 'Deprecate EnablePaunch and remove Paunch support

Paunch was deprecated in Ussuri and is now being retired, to be fully
replaced by the new tripleo-ansible role, tripleo_container_manage.

This patch:

- Removes common/container-puppet.py (was only useful when paunch is
  enabled, since that script was converted to container_puppet_config
  Ansible module in tripleo-ansible).
- Update all comments refering to paunch, and replace by
  tripleo_container_manage.
- Deprecate EnablePaunch parameter.
- Remove paunch as python dependencies.

Change-Id: I9294677fa18a7efc61898a25103414c8191d8805
'}, {'created': '2020-05-28 21:39:57.000000000', 'message': 'Deprecate EnablePaunch and remove Paunch support

commit_message:
Deprecate EnablePaunch and remove Paunch support

Paunch was deprecated in Ussuri and is now being retired, to be fully
replaced by the new tripleo-ansible role, tripleo_container_manage.

This patch:

- Removes common/container-puppet.py (was only useful when paunch is
  enabled, since that script was converted to container_puppet_config
  Ansible module in tripleo-ansible).
- Update all comments refering to paunch, and replace by
  tripleo_container_manage.
- Deprecate EnablePaunch parameter.
- Remove paunch as python dependencies.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/731545/
Change-Id: I9294677fa18a7efc61898a25103414c8191d8805

commit_message:
Use default bindep_profile for wheels

Revert part of I69254919958cec67095b25724b417282e1f270f8, bindep.txt in
requirements is used for generate-constraints as well, a special wheel
profile does not help. Use the default profile, like we use for
generate-constraints as part of proposal job.

Change-Id: I229e06579849c9fffa00ef33aa94d730331110d3

commit_message:
Add additional files to ipa standalone test

The added files contain composable services that define
certificate_specs and therefore create certificates when
configured with tls-everywhere.

Change-Id: I08fe238da5cf379b1d5c607b2c544f971e0211be
(cherry picked from commit 1ed331a45b04baf6e020aa3124a02fe03da0f1e4)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-24 07:15:53.000000000', 'message': "Auto-sharding: Initial steps

This patch is starting to set up the code to support
auto-sharding 2.0. This is the start of a patch chain
that will attempt to implement what was discussed at
the PTG in denver[0].

The next auto-shard version will continue to use Sam's
index 0 node to be the leader, but will also use ring
version counter to strip ignore any old nodes in the cluster.
This will require some quorum checks with other primary nodes.

The general plan is:
  - The scanner will use a 2 phase check.
\xa0\xa0- And a mix of historic versions 1 and 2:
\xa0\xa0  1. The scanner will use the 2 phase checking.
          am I index 0 > scan > am I still the scanner > commit shard ranges
\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa02. Use Sam's index 0, but also include the ring version when making a decision,
       as a way to discredit old primaries that are now handoff nodes
       (if they don't agree with the latest ring version).
\xa0 - To start with be extra cautious. NOT majority quorum _all_ primary quorum.
\xa0\xa0- Response from each primary during quorum check will be:
    1. who do you think index 0 is AND
    2. what is your current ring version.

This initial patch completes 2 preparations. Firstly plumbs the ringbuilder
version into RingData and into the Ring. Bonus drive by, now when you rebuild
the builder from a ring the version is maintained.

And secondly, creates an ELECT verb in the continer server that will
pull in the ring (when needed) and return a response with a json body
containing the node, partition and ring version that the sharder will
need to make a decision.

There is also a small amount of prep in the sharder.

Note, even this first patch is WIP, there was still tests and
documentation updates required to it before we can even think of landing
it.

[0] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift-ptg-train (see Sharding next
steps)

Change-Id: Ie105210fd4dc627d61d0cbd28fd468be4917f558

the ring, this has been pulled out into Tim's patch 670673, namely the ring version.

And secondly, creates an ELECT verb in the continer server that will
pull in the ring (when needed) and return a response with a json body
containing the node, partition and ring version that the sharder will
need to make a decision.

There is also a small amount of prep in the sharder.

Note, even this first patch is WIP, there was still tests and
documentation updates required to it before we can even think of landing
it.

commit_message:
Auto-sharding: Initial steps

This patch is starting to set up the code to support
auto-sharding 2.0. This is the start of a patch chain
that will attempt to implement what was discussed at
the PTG in denver[0].

The next auto-shard version will continue to use Sam's
index 0 node to be the leader, but will also use ring
version counter to strip ignore any old nodes in the cluster.
This will require some quorum checks with other primary nodes.

The general plan is:
  - The scanner will use a 2 phase check.
  - And a mix of historic versions 1 and 2:
    1. The scanner will use the 2 phase checking.
          am I index 0 > scan > am I still the scanner > commit shard ranges
    2. Use Sam's index 0, but also include the ring version when making a decision,
       as a way to discredit old primaries that are now handoff nodes
       (if they don't agree with the latest ring version).
  - To start with be extra cautious. NOT majority quorum _all_ primary quorum.
  - Response from each primary during quorum check will be:
    1. who do you think index 0 is AND
    2. what is your current ring version.

The autosharding needs to preperations. More info needs to be referencable from
the ring, this has been pulled out into Tim's patch 670673, namely the ring version.

And secondly, creates an ELECT verb in the continer server that will
pull in the ring (when needed) and return a response with a json body
containing the node, partition and ring version that the sharder will
need to make a decision.

There is also a small amount of prep in the sharder.

Note, even this first patch is WIP, there was still tests and
documentation updates required to it before we can even think of landing
it.

[0] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift-ptg-train (see Sharding next
steps)

Change-Id: Ie105210fd4dc627d61d0cbd28fd468be4917f558

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I91a2a6a66ad000052e8e35ee3e3314b45ec11ed6

commit_message:
Checkout diskimage-builder to 2.38.0 tag for CentOS-7

As python2 support removed from diskimage-builder,
many of the CentOS-7 jobs affacts the python version
issue.

This patch fixes the issue by checking dib to 2.38.0
Closes-Bug: #1881732

Change-Id: I55ac7af4887e54877518a25545116a5c3475ebd9

Congratulations, you've proposed your first change in OpenDev.

Your submission will now be tested automatically by Zuul, our gatekeeper,
and reviewed by other friendly developers. They will give you feedback and
may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches often take days (and sometimes weeks) to get reviewed, so be
patient. Don't hesitate to ask for help, and answer questions about your
work promptly if you can. The more you get to know reviewers and get to be
known by them, the smoother the review and approval process will become. The
fastest way to accomplish this is by reviewing other proposed changes
yourself: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for participating in OpenDev, we look forward to seeing you
around.

commit_message:
Make user provided content deployable

When src is provided to config_template module, content is simply
ignored. So we should set tmp_f only when content is not provided.
This also means that we should use native file lookup instead of
pipe.
Additionally when statements shouldn't include Jinja2 delimiters.

Change-Id: I9ff2fdea02ca71068dab9cfcab10ca60785821de
(cherry picked from commit f50ea4f5e18f4890864dc831f4f5f19aa5439af2)

commit_message:
Update minion rabbit credentials

By default the undercloud uses
deployment/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-messaging-notify-shared-puppet.yaml for the
notification messaging credentials. This services reuses the Rpc*
settings for the notify transport url. Previously the minion would split
out the notify and rpc transport urls. This doesn't work if the notify
credentials are never setup.

Closes-Bug: #1880956
Change-Id: I2b38cb1a2c4340ff173d349d0f3b49f6f4997262

commit_message:
Fix node scaling

The playbook fails when removing unreachable nodes from deployment with
`openstack overcloud delete node`. Some `ignore_unreachable: true` are
missing. Also, one cannot use `any_errors_fatal: true` when ignoring
unreachable nodes, otherwise the playbook execution will stop after the
current task.

Change-Id: Ibcb84e58bac1975490df281c0de950cdf74337b2

subject: Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-03 18:27:32.000000000', 'message': "Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I13e5de067ad381d058060bc5e297a0360804e119
"}]
commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I13e5de067ad381d058060bc5e297a0360804e119

commit_message:
Trigger a job to run a standalone deploy with IPA on multinode

This review triggers the job:
tripleo-ci-centos-8-standalone-on-multinode-ipa
to create a multinode setup of two nodes having FreeIPA
server along with standalone deployment

commit_message:
Update scn003 to exercise ExtraFirewallrules capabilities

This change will add a couple extra firewall rules to scenario 003
which will ensure we're exercising an optional code path, which
provides a functional example of how we can leverage the feature.

The scenario test matrix has been updated to indicate "extra firewall"
is tested in scn003.

Change-Id: I9db8e2acbacb820c3e8b6b2eb7a8a0dbbae4a089
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 69fe39c8e402875fd1a6bd55c136f4dd2a5d7bce)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 18:35:16.000000000', 'message': "Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I919ea4dcf0e61d16a10c68cecb341e108d76c4aa
"}]
commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I919ea4dcf0e61d16a10c68cecb341e108d76c4aa

commit_message:
Fix exception message

Fix some exception messages because some exception messages are not
outputed as expected.
In addition, the codes that seems to improve readability by explicitly
specifying the arguments are also modified.

Change-Id: I425d15ea9f5a3d0b6132ffd03cb577e583239c3a

commit_message:
Add user message when share shrinking fails at the driver

Not all drivers support share shrinking.
This patch adds a user message when shrinking fails due to operation
not being supported.

Change-Id: I5137cd972ec7737d70865038d7b82cfe13b9566c
Closes-Bug: #1802424

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-03 13:44:41.000000000', 'message': "Improve facter cache reliability

We don't need to be caching EC2 metadata in our facter runs because we
don't use this. By leaving this on, it can cause problems when run on
VMs in a cloud that might support EC2.  By having this enabled, we can
see deployments failing to configure nodes because it timesout:

2020-05-13 22:38:30.574339 ERROR puppetlabs.facter - EC2 user data
request failed: Timeout was reached

Additionally if facter fails to generate the cache, the subsequent
puppet runs will fail. This change also added retries to the facter
cache call to ensure that we should be able to generate the cache if an
external fact call fails for some reason.

NOTE: The master patch for this is against tripleo-ansible

Closes-Bug: #1861917
Change-Id: Iaaed0dcf747ca4a08f8e200b43d0f2259ad0ed39
(cherry-picked from c3b57d6a6c26acf35168fea7303fc485e1dcd13f)

(cherry-picked from c3b57d6a6c26acf35168fea7303fc485e1dcd13f)
"}]
commit_message:
Improve facter cache reliability

We don't need to be caching EC2 metadata in our facter runs because we
don't use this. By leaving this on, it can cause problems when run on
VMs in a cloud that might support EC2.  By having this enabled, we can
see deployments failing to configure nodes because it timesout:

2020-05-13 22:38:30.574339 ERROR puppetlabs.facter - EC2 user data
request failed: Timeout was reached

Additionally if facter fails to generate the cache, the subsequent
puppet runs will fail. This change also added retries to the facter
cache call to ensure that we should be able to generate the cache if an
external fact call fails for some reason.

NOTE: The master patch for this is against tripleo-ansible

Closes-Bug: #1861917
Change-Id: Iaaed0dcf747ca4a08f8e200b43d0f2259ad0ed39
(cherry-picked from c3b57d6a6c26acf35168fea7303fc485e1dcd13f)

messages: [{'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2020-06-02 05:38:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2020-06-03 00:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2020-06-04 01:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 05:38:51.000000000', 'message': "Add branch and tag tags to docker image

When building the docker image attempt to apply the git branch and git
tag as a docker hub tags. The code seems to suggest looping through the
tags, so if the git change doesn't have, say a tag, then it should be ''
and therefore not applied.

The downside I can see is that every change has a branch (stable or
master) so it might make the latest tag not be updated anymore.

I've only looked briefly at the code, so not sure will actually work.
But hoping it will ;)

commit_message:
Add branch and tag tags to docker image

When building the docker image attempt to apply the git branch and git
tag as a docker hub tags. The code seems to suggest looping through the
tags, so if the git change doesn't have, say a tag, then it should be ''
and therefore not applied.

The downside I can see is that every change has a branch (stable or
master) so it might make the latest tag not be updated anymore.

I've only looked briefly at the code, so not sure will actually work.
But hoping it will ;)

Change-Id: I0cdcc9f17fd4b46d513eb8c775c2e4983f948cd0

commit_message:
Improve facter cache reliability

We don't need to be caching EC2 metadata in our facter runs because we
don't use this. By leaving this on, it can cause problems when run on
VMs in a cloud that might support EC2.  By having this enabled, we can
see deployments failing to configure nodes because it timesout:

2020-05-13 22:38:30.574339 ERROR puppetlabs.facter - EC2 user data
request failed: Timeout was reached

Additionally if facter fails to generate the cache, the subsequent
puppet runs will fail. This change also added retries to the facter
cache call to ensure that we should be able to generate the cache if an
external fact call fails for some reason.

NOTE: The master patch for this is against tripleo-ansible

Closes-Bug: #1861917
Change-Id: Iaaed0dcf747ca4a08f8e200b43d0f2259ad0ed39

commit_message:
Configure SNMPD when telemetry is used

Users reported regression of missing SNMPD service. I wasn't able to find where got
it lost, so made this patch to explicitly configure the service as it is configured
on newer releases.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/732091
Change-Id: I35bbd300a63e05added1aa4dda38d12d0657c704
Partial-Bug: #1881152

commit_message:
Improve VNF packages API documentation

In this patch, improve VNF packages API documentation.

* Modify the reference yaml of inc file
Modify the reference yaml of 'vnf_packages.inc' from 'parameter.yaml' to 'parameters_vnf_packages.yaml'.
This is an improvement of the document structure.
(Like 'parameters_vnflcm.yaml'.)

* Modify key name of parameter to snake case
Modify key name of parameter included in 'parameters_vnf_packages.yaml' to snake_case.
Currently, snake_case and camelCase are mixed.

Change-Id: Ia90204bee90d0103bec6a23ccbdd70b33a6e1e70
Related-Bug: #1880110

commit_message:
Modify VNF packages API documentation

In this patch, modify VNF packages API documentation.
I modify the following 2 errors.

* Modify error of URI path
Upload VNF Package from uri
 - Incorrect:/vnf_packages/{vnf_package_id}/package_content/upload_from_uri
 - Correct:/vnfpkgm/v1/vnf_packages/{vnf_package_id}/package_content/upload_from_uri

* Modify error of request parameters
Upload VNF Package from uri
 - userName
 - password
These parameters are Optional but the notations are missing.
The other parameters are similarly modified.

Change-Id: I30ad2d3f3046993d18d1be410b1a9f007e583eff
Closes-Bug: #1880110

commit_message:
Exclude callbacks env vars for ceph-ansible

We're working on changing the default callbacks for tripleo but we don't
want to use them when invoking ceph-ansible. We should exclude the
callbacks that were used in the calling env and specifically set the
regular callbacks.

Change-Id: I6ab1709d2e0e0d60d2401281aa3bb88cfea6e5d4
Related-Bug: #1881670
(cherry picked from commit 64313d1f3534d20b4ba54ad68629c912a1ed2d9c)

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I8cad3acb05b29a76b160a3ba09608807e934a263
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 18:27:34.000000000', 'message': "Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I78eae580f3721a1b9fcca3cf9693afc26390f4d3
"}]
commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I78eae580f3721a1b9fcca3cf9693afc26390f4d3

commit_message:
[update] kibana : add install hook and dependencies

The flush-kibana-metadata job was causing issue in loading the kibana
dashboard due to conflict in order this is run. Adding dependencies to avoid
running jobs simultaneously.

Change-Id: If5a2564a8b6a16fb0dbd6a93f2e6e02d91f394dc

[{'created': '2020-05-27 21:48:49.000000000', 'message': 'Consolidate python memcache bindings install

Consolidate all the installs of python memcache
bindings to use ensure_package. Right now we are
mixing the usage of ensure_resources on some places
which causes redecalaration issues.

Since the resources need to be identical in order
to not raise redeclaration issues we cannot have
the horizon-package tag on the package.

Change-Id: I0a76cbe45774bbf6871c1803c056bc2f6b3b6c0d
(cherry picked from commit 3ec253827c10b81f61bf3b96cd85a50c2c264abc)

commit_message:
Consolidate python memcache bindings install

Consolidate all the installs of python memcache
bindings to use ensure_package. Right now we are
mixing the usage of ensure_resources on some places
which causes redecalaration issues.

Since the resources need to be identical in order
to not raise redeclaration issues we cannot have
the horizon-package tag on the package.

Change-Id: I0a76cbe45774bbf6871c1803c056bc2f6b3b6c0d
(cherry picked from commit 3ec253827c10b81f61bf3b96cd85a50c2c264abc)

commit_message:
at least one test needs to run for tempest to pass

when tempest_horizon.tests.scenario.test_
dashboard_basic_ops.TestDashboardBasicOps

skips the test, perhaps because the service
is not running or not discovered by
python-tempestconf or $other the job will fail.

Change-Id: Ief660053e78aecefdfacb5c9171d7c589223f08b

commit_message:
Move wheel build role/job outside project-config

We can not speculatively test changes to the wheel build jobs while it
is project config.  These jobs are in the gate for the requirements
project, which run them when bindep.txt changes.

https://review.opendev.org/731394 moved the build-wheel-mirror-base
job/playbook/role into openstack-zuul-jobs, renamed as
build-wheel-cache-* to a) distinguish the name and b) make it a little
clearer that we're building the wheels that goes on the mirror, rather
than passing through to mirroring something existing.

This updates the job names in project-config to reference these new
jobs.

Note the publishing steps are kept here along with the AFS secret.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/732085
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/732087
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/732083
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/732084
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/732086

Change-Id: Iac3a906803177e8365f4cfb611800b5ccaed4a6e

subject: Support overriding Horizon default openrc template
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-03 20:31:49.000000000', 'message': 'Support overriding Horizon default openrc template

Horizon has a capability (since Stein) of overriding the default OpenRC
template that it ships with. This can be useful for operators who wish
to customize the openrc scripts that users may be downloading from
Horizon, e.g., to change authentication methods or add additional
overrides/defaults.

Change-Id: I1e7ef02979eea07606594726453d82b2488f1fa7
'}]
commit_message:
Support overriding Horizon default openrc template

Horizon has a capability (since Stein) of overriding the default OpenRC
template that it ships with. This can be useful for operators who wish
to customize the openrc scripts that users may be downloading from
Horizon, e.g., to change authentication methods or add additional
overrides/defaults.

Change-Id: I1e7ef02979eea07606594726453d82b2488f1fa7

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I088f435bfc0dfeb67b4b2c3400aaa08eb41d7c59

commit_message:
Remove selinux relabel mount option for neutron

Neutron agent processes launched in containers are failing with
 "Error: relabel failed "/var/lib/neutron": \
  SELinux relabeling of /var/lib/neutron is not allowed"

Possibly related prior patch:
 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/626546/

Change-Id: Ifc7d0cb79214da44d9cd12481f010e2d7d325aa6
Related-Bug: #1881146

commit_message:
Remove selinux relabel mount option for neutron

Neutron agent processes launched in containers are failing with
 "Error: relabel failed "/var/lib/neutron": \
  SELinux relabeling of /var/lib/neutron is not allowed"

Possibly related prior patch:
 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/626546/

Change-Id: Ifc7d0cb79214da44d9cd12481f010e2d7d325aa6
Related-Bug: #1881146
(cherry picked from commit 3fa8c735ae75653284906e5a192391cd03a8431d)

commit_message:
Change the :Z mount flag to :z

Leaving this with the capital Z limits access to this file
to the other novajoin container. This can cause the other
container to malfunction. At the very best, the other
container will restart, relabeling the file with it's
settings, which has the proper value of lower z.

Closes-Bug: #1881713
Resolves: rhbz#1837141
Change-Id: Iebcfb9509c58619f9d68d3036775f07683a0fa42
(cherry picked from commit a6fa6027275bd650390cd538abffd7f06da24756)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-03 20:28:00.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Switch from retrying to tenacity"

This reverts commit 3f1314674d59bca6e9d0e43d4d479bb04f20aca1.

Turns out this causes problems for consuming code. Even if that
consuming code has unit tests that don't touch os-brick, because
tenacity is loaded when os-brick code is loaded, by the time
the consuming code mocks out the sleep call it is too late. So
any code that uses retries will end up actually sleeping and
retrying, often timing out the unit test because it takes too
long to complete.

This will have to be readdressed once a better way is figured
out for being able to safely mock these retry sleep calls.

Change-Id: Ieaaf03387685a4be2b709b48660483f71d41d461
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Switch from retrying to tenacity"

This reverts commit 3f1314674d59bca6e9d0e43d4d479bb04f20aca1.

Turns out this causes problems for consuming code. Even if that
consuming code has unit tests that don't touch os-brick, because
tenacity is loaded when os-brick code is loaded, by the time
the consuming code mocks out the sleep call it is too late. So
any code that uses retries will end up actually sleeping and
retrying, often timing out the unit test because it takes too
long to complete.

This will have to be readdressed once a better way is figured
out for being able to safely mock these retry sleep calls.

Change-Id: Ieaaf03387685a4be2b709b48660483f71d41d461

commit_message:
Change repository links usage in Dockerfile and build image

Used to be: git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-persister?h=stable/pike
Now : releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/pike

Since the way links to specific branches changed, usage of
those links has to be changed as well.
CONSTRAINTS_BRANCH variable was removed because CONSTRAINTS_FILE
contains link to the upper-requirements file with specified branch.

Change-Id: Ic67b2b30906768fa6249d10ed2c7e8037df0f544
Story: 2005666
Task: 30971

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: Ie26bca45202edae9114c63ef55af2b646f2e209b

'}, {'created': '2020-06-03 02:47:57.000000000', 'message': "openafs-rpm-package-build: new package build roles

The extant roles are not really right.  They run in periodic and poll
tarballs to see if they should build anything.  They are not gate
tested.  I do not know why I did it like this; but it was a long time
ago.

We should have roles that build in the check gate, and upload only
when the client version changes.

Additionally, I found that the upstream .srpm we were building from is
not quite right; it won't build on ARM64 for example due to the way
it's autoconf machinery has been generated.  The best way is to build
your own srpm from the upstream source using the method linked in this
change.

This builds and publishes artifacts for centos7 x86 and centos8
arm64/x86.  A follow-on will publish these.

Change-Id: Iefb01ba48a457388bb5412ddad3d7dafb00d620c

commit_message:
openafs-rpm-package-build: new package build roles

The extant roles are not really right.  They run in periodic and poll
tarballs to see if they should build anything.  They are not gate
tested.  I do not know why I did it like this; but it was a long time
ago.

We should have roles that build in the check gate, and upload only
when the client version changes.

Additionally, I found that the upstream .srpm we were building from is
not quite right; it won't build on ARM64 for example due to the way
it's autoconf machinery has been generated.  The best way is to build
your own srpm from the upstream source using the method linked in this
change.

This builds and publishes artifacts for centos7 x86 and centos8
arm64/x86.  A follow-on will publish these.

Change-Id: Iefb01ba48a457388bb5412ddad3d7dafb00d620c

commit_message:
Exclude callbacks env vars for ceph-ansible

We're working on changing the default callbacks for tripleo but we don't
want to use them when invoking ceph-ansible. We should exclude the
callbacks that were used in the calling env and specifically set the
regular callbacks.

Change-Id: I6ab1709d2e0e0d60d2401281aa3bb88cfea6e5d4
Related-Bug: #1881670
(cherry picked from commit 64313d1f3534d20b4ba54ad68629c912a1ed2d9c)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-06 00:54:36.000000000', 'message': 'Switch from retrying to tenacity

This switching our retry mechanism over from the retrying library to the
tenacity library. Retrying has been active for a few years now and
appears to be no longer maintained.

This has a small behavior change in that before we were applying an
exponential backoff to the first time a retry was needed. This no longer
happens, but retries will exponentially back off with each retry.

Also cleaned up some minor nits with unit test assert argument order.

Closes-bug: #1635397

Change-Id: I24cab206b16e63859d4886c55d40a03d398ce30d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-05-06 11:55:47.000000000', 'message': 'Switch from retrying to tenacity

This switching our retry mechanism over from the retrying library to the
tenacity library. Retrying has been active for a few years now and
appears to be no longer maintained.

This has a small behavior change in that before we were applying an
exponential backoff to the first time a retry was needed. This no longer
happens, but retries will exponentially back off with each retry.

Also cleaned up some minor nits with unit test assert argument order.

Change-Id: I24cab206b16e63859d4886c55d40a03d398ce30d

'}, {'created': '2020-05-06 14:08:07.000000000', 'message': 'Switch from retrying to tenacity

This switching our retry mechanism over from the retrying library to the
tenacity library. Retrying has been active for a few years now and
appears to be no longer maintained.

This has a small behavior change in that before we were applying an
exponential backoff to the first time a retry was needed. This no longer
happens, but retries will exponentially back off with each retry.

Also cleaned up some minor nits with unit test assert argument order.

Closes-bug: #1635397

commit_message:
Switch from retrying to tenacity

This switching our retry mechanism over from the retrying library to the
tenacity library. Retrying has been active for a few years now and
appears to be no longer maintained.

This has a small behavior change in that before we were applying an
exponential backoff to the first time a retry was needed. This no longer
happens, but retries will exponentially back off with each retry.

Also cleaned up some minor nits with unit test assert argument order.

Closes-bug: #1635397

Change-Id: I24cab206b16e63859d4886c55d40a03d398ce30d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

I think there's some argument to make for processing request params to
primitive types as early as possible but since _should_auto_create

Change-Id: I7b17c7377c128effe01bf35fc1ae8c058d2d8f77

commit_message:
Simplify container auto create param plumbing

I think there's some argument to make for processing request params to
primitive types as early as possible but since _should_auto_create
supports a ternary behavior (None, True, False) it seems better to lean
towards consolidation of logic.

Change-Id: I7b17c7377c128effe01bf35fc1ae8c058d2d8f77

and their follow-on patches.

messages: [{'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2020-06-01 09:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28062, 'date': '2020-06-03 13:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2020-06-03 19:36:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-01 09:49:53.000000000', 'message': 'Remove dependency on local hostname

The json_plugin tests read the localhost name in a different way
to how the hostname is fetched in the Monasca Agent check. This can
cause these tests to fail since the hostnames may differ. For example,
only one may contain .home as a suffix. In this change we avoid reading
the hostname from the system running the tests.

Story: 2007743
Task: 39921
Change-Id: Ifddba6aa9350f722a741a28a152ed9bc3e0b7da6
'}]
commit_message:
Remove dependency on local hostname

The json_plugin tests read the localhost name in a different way
to how the hostname is fetched in the Monasca Agent check. This can
cause these tests to fail since the hostnames may differ. For example,
only one may contain .home as a suffix. In this change we avoid reading
the hostname from the system running the tests.

Story: 2007743
Task: 39921
Change-Id: Ifddba6aa9350f722a741a28a152ed9bc3e0b7da6

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 18:34:38.000000000', 'message': "Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105

Change-Id: I292be888fef955705fae5e29c27d4083ae455d59
"}]
commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I292be888fef955705fae5e29c27d4083ae455d59

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using
this version will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using
this version will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Fix problems found by newer Sphinx version.

Change-Id: I480437115b4f216b28b87f2addf34721a8d27bd7

commit_message:
Make user provided content deployable

When src is provided to config_template module, content is simply
ignored. So we should set tmp_f only when content is not provided.
This also means that we should use native file lookup instead of
pipe.
Additionally when statements shouldn't include Jinja2 delimiters.

Change-Id: I9ff2fdea02ca71068dab9cfcab10ca60785821de

subject: relinker: Skip locked data dirs
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-03 18:06:25.000000000', 'message': 'relinker: Skip locked data dirs

Previously, the process would wait indefinitely to acquire the lock.

Now, warn about the locked directory, count it as an error for our
return code, and carry on.

Change-Id: I6673647b835b35d57372b842bca01b140cbd3cb6
'}]
commit_message:
relinker: Skip locked data dirs

Previously, the process would wait indefinitely to acquire the lock.

Now, warn about the locked directory, count it as an error for our
return code, and carry on.

Change-Id: I6673647b835b35d57372b842bca01b140cbd3cb6

commit_message:
Creating image-volume cache on NFS backend fails

snapshot.id doesn't have `tmp-snap` in it as id
is not passed as a option while creating snapshot
object. This should be change to
`snapshot.display_name` at same location

Closes-Bug: #1875570
Change-Id: I66da0212a61d778fe9795d382b3af5b225a8aa54

messages: [{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-06-02 14:32:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-06-02 14:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-06-03 12:26:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2020-06-03 18:51:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 14:32:19.000000000', 'message': "Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using
this version will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I77e62e13b1e08556bd47941613fa8be338eb8d9e
"}, {'created': '2020-06-02 14:33:47.000000000', 'message': "Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme version

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 version. Using
this version will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I77e62e13b1e08556bd47941613fa8be338eb8d9e

This topic has come up consistently since 2015. This commit links to
relevant discussions and describes the possible benefits of using
something other than keystone's service catalog implementation.

commit_message:
Add idea for alternative service catalogs

This topic has come up consistently since 2015. This commit links to
relevant discussions and describes the possible benefits of using
something other than keystone's service catalog implementation.

Someone should be able to read this and have enough information to do
a PoC if they find this work valuable or interesting.

Change-Id: Ida39478b67110793a4a660c76d4c68e3c7cd9f07

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Set openstackdocs_pdf_link to link to PDF file. Note that
the link to the published document only works on docs.openstack.org
where the PDF file is placed in the top-level html directory. The
site-preview places the PDF in a pdf directory.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

Remove docs requirements from lower-constraints, they are not needed
during install or test but only for docs building.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I131850d2a5c6164dfd48c9c95885d4754b5236c6

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 19:42:31.000000000', 'message': "Temporary disable requirements check

The requirements repo is support python 3.5 as oldest python version
while swift still supports py27.

thus, requirements-check will fail on a couple of lines in swift. The
check is only run when these files are touched. Let's disable the check,
merge a few changes to these files and enable again.

Change-Id: Ibf8000498528c401707be8b0b91b8355cd993786
"}, {'created': '2020-06-02 22:05:51.000000000', 'message': 'Remove <py3.5 dependencies from requirements.txt

The requirements repo is support python 3.5 as oldest python version
while swift still supports py27.

thus, requirements-check will fail on a couple of lines in swift.  The
check is only run when these files are touched.

The py2.7 packagers we know about aren't depending on upstream
requirements.txt for correctness and aside from all the production
deployments running on py2.7 we only realistically support >=py3.7

There's no good reason for our requirements.txt to be "unspported" by
the openstack requirements check job.  Since they only support >=py3.5
we can change our requirements.txt inline with that.  This should be
fine for everything we could hope to get out of both our
requirements.txt and the check!

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ibf8000498528c401707be8b0b91b8355cd993786

thus, requirements-check will fail on a couple of lines in swift.  The

The py2.7 packagers we know about aren't depending on upstream

There's no good reason for our requirements.txt to be "unspported" by

commit_message:
Remove <py3.5 dependencies from requirements.txt

The requirements repo is support python 3.5 as oldest python version
while swift still supports py27.

thus, requirements-check will fail on a couple of lines in swift.  The
check is only run when these files are touched.

The py2.7 packagers we know about aren't depending on upstream
requirements.txt for correctness and aside from all the production
deployments running on py2.7 we only realistically support >=py3.7

There's no good reason for our requirements.txt to be "unspported" by
the openstack requirements check job.  Since they only support >=py3.5
we can change our requirements.txt inline with that.  This should be
fine for everything we could hope to get out of both our
requirements.txt and the check!

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ibf8000498528c401707be8b0b91b8355cd993786

commit_message:
Update docstheme for style

New version of openstackdocstheme (Victoria+) respects pygments_style.
Since this repo is using now Victoria (master) requirements but has
not branched for Ussuri yet, it uses the new version.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

Change-Id: I3f92dfbbd1bdbc95d9157dd7a0af4002366199fc

[{'created': '2020-05-25 21:53:39.000000000', 'message': "Add in-tree upper-constraints for py35 job

It is difficult to keep the py35 upper constraints on reqiorements
repo's upper-constarint.txt file as update-constraint tools generate
the new file everytime with official supported python version only
which is py3.6 and py3.8 for Victoria cycle
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/730428

Let's keep the py3.5 constraints in-tree which can be used in py35
unit test job.

Change-Id: Iec2eaa2b7e8df777b6988c2134e7771b9b1fb5b5

commit_message:
Add in-tree upper-constraints for py35 job

It is difficult to keep the py35 upper constraints on reqiorements
repo's upper-constarint.txt file as update-constraint tools generate
the new file everytime with official supported python version only
which is py3.6 and py3.8 for Victoria cycle
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/730428

Let's keep the py3.5 constraints in-tree which can be used in py35
unit test job.

Change-Id: Iec2eaa2b7e8df777b6988c2134e7771b9b1fb5b5

yes that'd be useful, thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2020-05-04 16:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

Generally speaking, this LGTM - it seems like this will result in some more simplification while still remaining decoupled through a strong interface which we can evolve to suit without our exclusive needs.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-05 11:01:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Emilien, thanks for clarification.
Mind adding those milestones and guarantees into the spec?'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-05 11:12:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

also please note about keeping supporting users' custom overrides via tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-05-05 14:22:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> also please note about keeping supporting users' custom overrides
 > via tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2

I don't think we want to support overrides. If you need to override something, users will have to create a new layer on top and do what they need. The whole goal of this is to not have overrides."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-05-05 14:39:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

The goal here is to not continue the pattern of previous versions. By declaring a structure we allow anyone to copy the structure and append or amend to rebuild. This is something that kolla has never really provided because the container structure was built into the code itself  vs having the code and the declarations of the containers as separate entities and the assumption that a user would pass in a structure containing the containers to build'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-05-08 03:55:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-05-08 03:56:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: -Code-Review

removing +2 as I'm co-author, my bad."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2020-05-08 18:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

The effort here seems to be about forking container build efforts in OpenStack to optimize some things about container generation and the resulting image layers. Rather than fork the community building efforts around building containers perhaps there is some layering work that could be done in Kolla to better support optimized image layers. Less base image layers, etc that might end up with less being copied around.

Also, This seems like a good bit of work for something we think might help, but it might not. Do we have some hard numbers on how the Kolla container image formats are negatively impacting deployments today?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2020-05-08 18:58:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

perhaps another way to look at the problem here is could we maintain a common interface? (kolla_start, kolla_config, etc) but have opinionated layering as part of the build scripts? Seems there is some common ground still'}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2020-05-12 15:36:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)

Since this describes a new configuration format, could we use proper type or a json schemas for it please?'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-05-12 21:41:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-05-12 22:23:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2020-05-19 16:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-05-19 20:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-05-19 20:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

I support the idea, but I believe we should wait until after the PTG to land this'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-28 08:05:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-2

I have doubts about adding that extra maintenance burden into tripleo.
The WIP patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722486/ that implements it is ~2800 LOC. This really looks like should stay in Kolla and wokred out collaboratively to reach our goals'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-05-28 12:45:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> I have doubts about adding that extra maintenance burden into
 > tripleo.
 > The WIP patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722486/ that
 > implements it is ~2800 LOC. This really looks like should stay in
 > Kolla and wokred out collaboratively to reach our goals

Note, much of the noted LOC is us vendoring the scripts we rely on, which came directly out of Kolla; this accounts for 1107 LOC. These scripts will be refactored (removed, minimized, simplified) in our second phase. If we take our the conversion tooling we wrote (which would have no maintenance burden, we just included it because we thought it was useful) this total review would be 1448, and is considerably more maintainable than our current set of overrides, without being much larger than the template file noted here: [ https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/src/commit/db3ad3558c36588bec4c2a032c87d10149c229f5/container-images/tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2 ].'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-28 13:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

will not block it though'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2020-06-03 18:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-06-03 18:02:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Add spec for simple container generation

This spec has been drafted to highlight an effort to improve the container
generation process and life cycle management of our applications.

Change-Id: I369c9a9f450c220d8cdc2827460de56ff1e4fb57
Co-authored-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove VxFlex OS credentials from connection_properties

VxFlex OS password is not stored in block_device_mapping table. Instead of this
passwords are stored in separate file and are retrieved during each attach/detach
operation.

Closes-Bug: #1823200
Change-Id: Iab54c515fe7be252df52b1a0503a251779805759

subject: Make header Case Insensitive
messages:
[{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-29 21:13:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-05-29 21:17:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Awesome.

However - http headers are actually case-insensitive, so I'd argue it's a bug that this matters. Perhaps instead of having headers be a {}, we should use requests.structures.CaseInsensitiveDict"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-29 21:31:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

> Awesome.
 > 
 > However - http headers are actually case-insensitive, so I'd argue
 > it's a bug that this matters. Perhaps instead of having headers be
 > a {}, we should use requests.structures.CaseInsensitiveDict

thanks, updating with that."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-29 22:21:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-05-30 20:24:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Comment typo, but otherwise looks good.

I don't suppose we can just make sure it is properly cased in all instances?"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-05-31 14:26:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Sean - there's no such thing as properly cased (that previous patch made them consistent, I requested this approach) because http headers are case insensitive."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-05-31 15:16:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, I meant bring consistent in our setting of the header so there is no duplication.'}, {'account_id': 26285, 'date': '2020-05-31 15:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2020-06-03 16:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-29 21:13:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix global-request-id header name

In case of global-request-id request, Adapter
send two global request id header
 - "X-OpenStack-Request-ID"
 - "X-Openstack-Request-Id".

Example: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/c5b1debf78df4aa3bdda34f0b4c53c37/log/testrepository.subunit#2385

This is becasue of the different header name in when
adaptor add or when session request add it, differnce
is with cap 'D'.

Unit test for whether request global-request-id has precedence
over adapter fail many times because of how different python version
treat the dict. py3.6 and above are all good as dict maintain the
insertion ordered but py3.5 can fail it any time.

We can see consistent failure in py35 jobs:
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/730687/

Let's use the header name from sessions global var to
make it consistent and no chance of having/comparing different
header.

Change-Id: Iba707dd0506d22e144aca4fdfc9b140c8e37ae02
Closes-Bug: #1881351
'}, {'created': '2020-05-29 22:21:46.000000000', 'message': 'Make header Case Insensitive

In case of global-request-id request, Adapter
send two global request id header
 - "X-OpenStack-Request-ID"
 - "X-Openstack-Request-Id".

Example: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/c5b1debf78df4aa3bdda34f0b4c53c37/log/testrepository.subunit#2385

This is becasue of the header not being Case Insensitive
and end up with two different name of same header with difference
of cap 'D'.

Unit test for whether request global-request-id has precedence
over adapter fail many times because of how different python version
treat the dict. py3.6 and above are all good as dict maintain the
insertion ordered but py3.5 can fail it any time.

We can see consistent failure in py35 jobs:
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/730687/

Let's make the headers always Case Insensitive which is
what RFC says.

Change-Id: Iba707dd0506d22e144aca4fdfc9b140c8e37ae02
Closes-Bug: #1881351
'}]
commit_message:
Make header Case Insensitive

In case of global-request-id request, Adapter
send two global request id header
 - "X-OpenStack-Request-ID"
 - "X-Openstack-Request-Id".

Example: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/c5b1debf78df4aa3bdda34f0b4c53c37/log/testrepository.subunit#2385

This is becasue of the header not being Case Insensitive
and end up with two different name of same header with difference
of cap 'D'.

Unit test for whether request global-request-id has precedence
over adapter fail many times because of how different python version
treat the dict. py3.6 and above are all good as dict maintain the
insertion ordered but py3.5 can fail it any time.

We can see consistent failure in py35 jobs:
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/730687/

Let's make the headers always Case Insensitive which is
what RFC says.

Change-Id: Iba707dd0506d22e144aca4fdfc9b140c8e37ae02
Closes-Bug: #1881351

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Set openstackdocs_pdf_link to link to PDF file. Note that
the link to the published document only works on docs.openstack.org
where the PDF file is placed in the top-level html directory. The
site-preview places the PDF in a pdf directory.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: I19b302e4ecd1e304302775d1f60609f2e43a944c

these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Set openstackdocs_pdf_link to link to PDF file. Note that
the link to the published document only works on docs.openstack.org
where the PDF file is placed in the top-level html directory. The
site-preview places the PDF in a pdf directory.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Change-Id: Iecdabf6ad83d4f75977dae880be52cf16474eb0a
